level.text: In rejecting goods, a lessee's failure to state a particular defect that is ascertainable by reasonable inspection precludes the lessee from relying on the defect to justify rejection or to establish default:
If, stated seasonably, the lessor or the supplier could have cured it (§ 28:2A-513); or
Between merchants if the lessor or the supplier after rejection has made a request in writing for a full and final written statement of all defects on which the lessee proposes to rely.
A lessee's failure to reserve rights when paying rent or other consideration against documents precludes recovery of the payment for defects apparent in the documents.

level.heading: Effect of Amendments
level.text: The 2013 amendment by D.C. Law 19-299 substituted "apparent in the documents" for "apparent on the face of the documents" in (b).

level.heading: Legislative History of Law 9-128
level.text: For legislative history of D.C. Law 9-128, see Historical and Statutory Notes following § 28:2A-101.

level.heading: Changes:
level.text: Revised to reflect leasing practices and terminology.

level.heading: Purposes:
level.text: The principles applicable to the commercial practice of payment against documents (subsection 2) are explained in official comment 4 to Section 2-605, the statutory analogue to this section.
